title.english: Saint Seiya: Knights of the Zodiac

description:
Ages ago, the goddess Athena was served by fighters called Saints who channeled the power of the Cosmos within them. Now a youth named Seiya has trained to become a Saint himself by earning the mystical Cloth of Pegasus. He is joined by other Saints with Cloths of their own to fight for Athena.

(Source: Anime News Network)
synonyms: Saint Seiya: Los Caballeros del Zodiaco

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Primarily Male Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of male characters.

tags.name: Mythology
tags.description: Prominently features mythological elements, especially those from religious or cultural tradition.

tags.name: Gods
tags.description: Prominently features a character of divine or religious nature.

tags.name: Orphan
tags.description: Prominently features a character that is an orphan.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Astronomy
tags.description: Relating or centered around the study of celestial objects and phenomena, space, or the universe.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Foreign
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a country outside the country of origin.

tags.name: Henshin
tags.description: Prominently features character or costume transformations which often grant special abilities.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

node.description:
__Height:__ 153 cm

Mitsuko Horie is a Japanese seiyuu and singer. She was born in Yamato, Kanagawa, Japan. She is most known to American anime fans as the voice of Sailor Galaxia, but in all Latin-America she is know as the "Candy-Candy" opening theme singer.
With the band Make-Up, he recorded several songs for the anime Saint Seiya, including the first opening song Pegasus Fantasy and the first ending song Blue Forever.

Araki developed an interest for drawing at age five. He graduated in Aichi Prefecture. In 1955, at age eighteen, he debuted as a cartoonist in the "Machi" magazine. He then joined Mushi Production as animator in 1964 and later founded Studio Jaccard in 1966. In 1970, he debuted as animation director on [Ashita no Joe](https://anilist.co/anime/2402/), and later worked on the anime adaptations of several of [Gou Nagai](https://anilist.co/staff/97992/)'s manga, including [Devilman](https://anilist.co/anime/2252/), [Cutie Honey](https://anilist.co/anime/1661/), and [UFO Robo Grendizer](https://anilist.co/anime/1985/), serving as a character designer on the latter two. In 1971 he founded Studio Z together with his friends in the business.

He frequently worked with animator [Michi Himeno](https://anilist.co/staff/113357/), who he met in 1973. Araki formed Araki Production in 1974 and Himeno was the first member of the studio.

Araki was also an animator on several American productions which outsourced animation work to Japan, including Mighty Orbots (1984, key animation), The Adventures of the American Rabbit (1986) and G.I. Joe: The Movie (1987).

He passed away due to heart failure on December 1, 2011.

Araki developed an interest for drawing at age five. He graduated in Aichi Prefecture. In 1955, at age eighteen, he debuted as a cartoonist in the "Machi" magazine. He then joined Mushi Production as animator in 1964 and later founded Studio Jaccard in 1966. In 1970, he debuted as animation director on [Ashita no Joe](https://anilist.co/anime/2402/), and later worked on the anime adaptations of several of [Gou Nagai](https://anilist.co/staff/97992/)'s manga, including [Devilman](https://anilist.co/anime/2252/), [Cutie Honey](https://anilist.co/anime/1661/), and [UFO Robo Grendizer](https://anilist.co/anime/1985/), serving as a character designer on the latter two. In 1971 he founded Studio Z together with his friends in the business.

He frequently worked with animator [Michi Himeno](https://anilist.co/staff/113357/), who he met in 1973. Araki formed Araki Production in 1974 and Himeno was the first member of the studio.

Araki was also an animator on several American productions which outsourced animation work to Japan, including Mighty Orbots (1984, key animation), The Adventures of the American Rabbit (1986) and G.I. Joe: The Movie (1987).

He passed away due to heart failure on December 1, 2011.
Japanese animator and director working as a freelancer, mainly at Toei Animation.

Edu Falaschi was the lead singer of the Brazilian power metal band Angra from 2001 to 2012, also performing as the vocalist for the heavy metal band Almah and on a solo carrer since 2016. Edu performed the Brazilian Portuguese versions of "Pegasus Fantasy" and "Blue Forever" for the Saint Seiya anime. He also performed a Brazilian Portuguese version of "Never" for the Saint Seiya: The Heaven Chapter movie.

Seiji Yokoyama was a prolific Japanese incidental music composer from Hiroshima who was best known for his work on the Space Pirate Captain Harlock and Saint Seiya series. He was a graduate student of Kunitachi College of Music.

He made his debut as a composer for the ending theme of The Adventures of Hutch the Honeybee in 1971. He was known for his symphonic sound for many television programs.

On July 8, 2017, Seiji Yokoyama died from pneumonia.

(Source: Wikipedia)
Also is a writer, producer and director for ADV Films and Robotboy Films.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/森下孝三)

The managing director of [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/).
Machiko Ryuu is a lyricist and translator.

__[Twitter](https://twitter.com/tadanonatsu)__

Natsumi Tadano is a Japanese lyricist.
